dc:description:
*C1QA* encodes the A-chain of the complement component C1Q, a core part of the C1 complex—the first component of the classical complement pathway. Together with C1R and C1S, C1Q forms a complex essential for immune defense by binding to pathogens or immune complexes and initiating complement activation. *C1QA* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in 1995 (PMID: 7594474). 

Twelve variants (4 nonsense, 4 frameshift, 1 splicing and 3 missense) that have been reported in 26 probands in 12 publications (PMIDs: 7594474, 8840296, 9039514, 9225968, 21654842, 26563161, 29739689, 30008451, 35086391, 39196411, 38263665, 22576477) are included in this curation. These variants are identified in both homozygous and compound heterozygous states in affected individuals. All probands exhibit confirmed C1Q deficiency, presenting with SLE or SLE-like clinical features and recurrent infections. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached.
 
The mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function. This gene-disease association is further supported by substantial experimental evidence, including gene expression analyses, animal models, and in vitro functional assays. In affected individuals, C1Q protein is undetectable in serum, and classical pathway hemolytic complement activity (CH50) is absent. Anti-C1Q autoantibodies, which are commonly observed in SLE patients, have been shown to correlate with renal disease activity and serve as a predictive biomarker for lupus nephritis (PMID: 15286009). Moreover, C1QA-deficient mice develop a lupus-like autoimmune phenotype characterized by antinuclear autoantibodies and glomerulonephritis (PMIDs: 9590289, 11859149, 29724957). Mechanistically, C1QA deficiency leads to defective clearance of apoptotic cells, resulting in increased exposure to self-antigens and breakdown of immune tolerance (PMIDs: 9590289, 10934224). Elevated production of interferon-alpha (IFN-α) has also been implicated in disease pathogenesis, representing a potential link between C1Q deficiency and autoimmunity (PMID: 19790049). Notably, C1Q may also limit autoreactivity in CD8+ T cells by modulating mitochondrial metabolism (PMID: 29724957). Bone marrow transplantation restores C1Q production and function in deficient mice (PMIDs: 11564823, 15517607), and treatment with fresh frozen plasma has been utilized to manage SLE associated with C1Q deficiency in human cases  (PMID:29113537).
 
In summary, there is **definitive** evidence supporting the relationship between C1QA and autosomal recessive Systemic Lupus Erythematosus. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Monogenic Systemic and Incomplete Lupus Erythematosus GCEP on the meeting date March 12, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: The study utilized a chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) model, which is an induced model rather than a spontaneous one, to explore systemic lupus erythematosus.
C1q restrains the response to self-antigens by modulating the mitochondrial metabolism of CD8+ T cells, which can themselves propagate autoimmunity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ling 2018 Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: The study did not assess the lupus phenotype following BMT.
Serum levels of C1q Ag and C1 function increased rapidly in the recipient mice, and titers reached normal levels within 6 wk after bone marrow transplantation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Petry 2001 Rescue in Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: C57BL/6 C1qa-/- mice show no evidence of autoimmunity.
Autoantibody production and the prevalence and severity of GN were significantly increased in MRL/Mp+/+ C1qa−/− mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mitchell  2002 Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: The study utilized a chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) model, which is an induced model rather than a spontaneous one, to explore systemic lupus erythematosus.
CD8+ T cell-depleted C1qa−/− animals displayed a progressive decline in lupus-associated autoantibodies.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ling 2018 Rescue in Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: All symptoms improved by daily fresh frozen plasma (FFP) infusions.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ekinci 2018 Rescue in human

evidence.dc:description: C1q-deficient (129 x C57BL/6) hybrid mice develop a syndrome reminiscent of human systemic lupus erythematosus.
evidence.rdfs:label: Botto et al 1998 Mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Restoration of C1q levels by bone marrow transplantation attenuates autoimmune disease associated with C1q deficiency in mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue in Mouse Model-BMC reconstitution

evidence.dc:description: C1q-deficient macrophages from three C1q-deficient humans with SLE showed a defect in the phagocytic uptake of apoptotic cells in vitro. This defect was corrected, in a dose-dependent manner, using purified C1q protein.
evidence.rdfs:label: Impaired apoptotic cell phagocytosis by patient macrophages

evidence.dc:description: CH50 was not tested for patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: CH50 activity was absent on complement testing

evidence.dc:description: A significant delay in the clearance of apoptotic cells was observed in C1qa-deficient mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Impaired apoptotic cell phagocytosis in C1qa-/- macrophages

evidence.dc:description: C1q inhibits immune complex-induced interferon-alpha production in plasmacytoid dendritic cells: a novel link between C1q deficiency and systemic lupus erythematosus pathogenesis.
evidence.rdfs:label: C1q and IFN-α production in SLE

evidence.dc:description: Anti-C1q in SLE are associated with renal involvement.
evidence.rdfs:label: Anti-C1q antibodies in lupus nephritis

evidence.dc:description: No C1q was detectable in patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Undetectable C1q in Complement Assays

evidence.dc:description: Insufficient evidence is available to support that the variant has arisen in different populations.
Serum levels of the C1q protein weremeasured and found to be much lower than normal ranges.

The variant has already been scored in the Turkish population, and there is insufficient evidence to support that this variant has arisen independently in different populations or that the cases are unrelated. To avoid overscoring and maintain a conservative approach, it is recommended to downgrade this case to 0 points.
No C1q protein was detectable. Classical pathway hemolytic complement activity (CH50) was zero.

There is insufficient evidence to support that this variant has arisen independently in different populations or that the cases are unrelated. To avoid overscoring and maintain a conservative approach, it is recommended to downgrade this case to 0 points.
Premature translational stop signal has been observed in individual(s) with C1q deficiency
Patients R and T are siblings and they are cousins of patient J. Consanguinity was confirmed. Only one proband from the family will be scored. The evidence would otherwise be overweighted.
The child was found to be functionally and antigenically homozygous deficient for Clq.

evidence.rdfs:label: Petry Patient T
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The patient suffered from SLE-like symptoms and recurrent bacterial infections

evidence.dc:description: The patients exhibited SLE-like symptoms, but the specific clinical information is unclear, and it is unknown whether they meet the full diagnostic criteria for SLE.
The child was found to be functionally and antigenically homozygous deficient for Clq.

evidence.rdfs:label: Petry Patient R
evidence.detectionMethod:
Cloned DNA was sequenced using double stranded plasmid DNA and Sequenase version
2 sequencing kit (United States Biochemical).
In contrast to DNA from normal individuals, DNA from the related patients T, R, and J could not be
digested, indicating that the same mutation was present in all three of them.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The patient suffered from SLE-like symptoms and recurrent bacterial infections.

This sequence change falls in intron 2 of the C1QA gene.  Algorithms developed to predict the effect of sequence changes on RNA splicing suggest that this variant may disrupt the consensus splice site. In the absence of direct evidence, classify the variant as predicted to affect splicing but not as a proven null allele.
Low C1q levels
